name: Joseph Wang
title: Markets Weekly February 15, 2025
text:
Synopsis
The global economic landscape is experiencing significant shifts, with potential geopolitical tensions, changing trade dynamics, and emerging opportunities in European markets driven by potential peace negotiations and increased military spending.

Key Insights
- US inflation data showed a higher-than-expected 0.5% month-over-month increase, causing initial market panic that quickly subsided
- Trump Administration is preparing to implement reciprocal tariffs targeting European goods, potentially starting April 2nd
- Potential end to Russia-Ukraine conflict could significantly benefit European economies, particularly Germany
- European stock markets are surging, outperforming US markets for the first time in years
- Potential European fiscal stimulus through increased military spending could boost economic growth
- US-European relations are strained, with questions about NATO alliance commitment and democratic values
- Energy prices in Europe are expected to decrease if Russia-Ukraine peace is achieved, improving economic competitiveness
- Unemployment and inflation metrics may not accurately reflect the economic experiences of middle and lower-class Americans
- The Trump Administration is considering value-added tax and non-tariff barriers as potential trade negotiation tools
- Potential rebuilding efforts in Ukraine could create significant economic opportunities
